entry.title: Cycle this epic section of the new Great American Rail-Trail
entry.summary:
Palouse Falls is one of many sites that can be visited by travelling the Great American Rail-Trail. The Great American Rail-Trail will cross the entire country when completed, but one of the most epic sections has already opened in Washington state.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
It takes but a minute to put wheels in motion for one of the greatest adventures you can have in America, yet nearly three months to experience it in full. Running from Washington State to Washington, DC, the 3,700-mile Great American Rail-Trail moves from Pacific waves and old-growth forests at its western end to the White House and the Capitol in the east.
Its east-west spine is made up of abandoned rail corridors that morph into urban greenways. Along the wa‚Ä¶

entry.title: Unraveling the mysteries of the world‚Äôs most critical rainforest
entry.summary:
Within the dense canopy of the Congo Basin Rainforest, the afternoon light began to fade, glinting off a soaring metal tower that rose steeply out of the jungle. Measuring 180 feet tall, the narrow steel structure resembled a massive cellular-network antenna, although it was outfitted with a collection of far more critical scientific sensors. The wind had picked up, causing the spire to sway and whine with each strong gust. But a biologist named Fabrice Kimbesa appeared undaunted. After strapping into a safety harness, he grabbed hold of a thin metal ladder and clambered briskly upward, leaving me to catch up as he raced toward a small platform at the very top.
This particular structure is what‚Äôs known as an eddy covariance flux tower. When it came online in October 2020, it became th‚Ä¶

entry.title: These fish swam with the dinosaurs. They may not survive us.
entry.summary:
The white sturgeon is the largest freshwater fish in North America; it can grow upwards of 15 feet. Here, in Idaho‚Äôs Snake River, state fishery officials tag an eight-footer. For 162 million years, sturgeons have fended off everything they‚Äôve faced. Now scientists are racing to save these living fossils.
The river flows vast and¬†soundless. It‚Äôs December in southern Kazakhstan, and the landscape near the Syr Darya River is smudged in shades of brown and taupe‚Äîdormant grasses, silted floodplains, leafless trees. This is not the most picturesque stretch of riverbank, strewn as it is with food wrappers, bottles, a decomposing sedan. Overhead, the sun is obscured by a haze of coal- and woodsmoke. But when it comes to what Bernie Kuhajda is searching for, the spot feels perfect.
‚ÄúTh‚Ä¶

entry.title: The stunning power of whale pee
entry.summary:
For too long, Humpback whales' urinary contributions to the ocean have been overlooked. A single whale can produce more than 250 gallons of urine in a day. It helps sustain life across the ocean.
In the deep blue water, a one-month-old humpback whale nuzzles up to its mother. Then, a cloud of dark yellow urine gushes into the water, like a golden smoke bomb, and everything becomes tinged with green.¬†
This footage provides a new clue to an important ingredient for a healthy ocean: whale wee. ¬†
Scientists have spent a lot of time thinking about how the nutrients in whale feces‚Äîalso known as whale pump‚Äîbenefit species in shallow waters, as whales swim up from the deep sea, where they feed, to poop near the surface.
But they had overlooked another important nutrient sou‚Ä¶

entry.title: The ultimate guide to the 2025 Jubilee in Rome
entry.summary:
Pope Francis opened Saint Peter's Basilica's holy door for Jubilee 2025, the Catholic's holy year, at the Vatican on Christmas Eve 2024. More crowds than usual are expected this year in the Eternal City. We explain what the Jubilee is, how to navigate the crowds, and what to see and do while there.
A trip to Rome is an exhilarating experience at any time. But with the Catholic Church‚Äôs Jubilee currently hitting its stride, 2025 is gearing up to be an even bigger year than usual.
The Jubilee is expected to draw more than 30 million visitors to the Eternal City, which has spent billions of euros cleaning up its monuments and upgrading its transport networks in preparation for the event. People are already starting to trickle in, so if you‚Äôre planning to come later in the year, b‚Ä¶

entry.title: A ‚Äòblood moon‚Äô total lunar eclipse is coming‚Äîhere‚Äôs when to watch
entry.summary:
People gather to watch a ‚Äúblood moon‚Äú eclipse in Melbourne, Australia, on July 28, 2018. On March 13-14, 2025, skywatchers across North America will have a prime view as the Moon turns red during a total lunar eclipse‚Äîthe first visible in the region since 2022. Skywatchers across the world will witness the first total lunar eclipse in three years. Here‚Äôs who will have the best views‚Äîand what gives the moon its eerie red tint.
For the first time since 2022, skywatchers across North America will see the full moon slip into Earth‚Äôs shadow, transforming into a deep reddish hue. The event begins after midnight on March 14 in the eastern U.S. and Canada, while those in the western half of the continent will see it unfold before midnight on March 13. Here‚Äôs what causes this phenomenon and‚Ä¶

entry.title: Can this graphic novel change America's views on climate? It did in France.
entry.summary:
Jean-Marc Jancovici is a rare specimen: a climate and energy nerd who is also something of a rock star. In the early 2000s, the French author and engineering consultant devised a carbon accounting system that is now widely used by companies in Europe to track their greenhouse gas emissions. Around the same time, he began giving lectures on climate change, videos of which went viral in France and eventually attracted the attention of Christophe Blain, a graphic novelist, who invited Jancovici to collaborate on a book.
Le Monde sans Fin, published in October 2021, explains Jancovici‚Äôs overarching theses: why fossil fuels will not be easy to abandon, and why and how we must do so anyway. It became the single bestselling book in France in 2022, ultimately selling more than a million copie‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why sleep tourism is the latest travel trend to know about
entry.summary:
London‚Äôs Kimpton Fitzroy offers a Room to Dream package that focuses on lucid dreaming. Across the world, resorts and retreats are using the latest technology alongside holistic practices to create dedicated sleep-improving programmes.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Scrolling through social media over a morning coffee, you‚Äôre just as likely to see someone sharing their sleep tracker data as a sunrise yoga session or breakfast smoothie. Amid the so-called sleep epidemic ‚Äî in the UK, 74% of adults report sleeping badly, and research suggests that 5-7% are seeing their GP to complain about fatigue ‚Äî a solid eight-hour sleep has become a sought-after luxury and something we‚Äôre all keen to shout about. entry.title: WHO injects fresh support into DR Congo vaccination drive
entry.summary: The UN World Health Organization (WHO) has stepped up efforts to improve vaccination coverage in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) by providing vital logistical support, including boats and motorcycles to reach remote communities along the Congo River.

entry.title: Women still face inequalities, despite the 19th Amendment
entry.summary:
Women line up to vote for the first time in New York City in 1920, after the passage of the 19th Amendment. Women won the right to vote more than a century ago, but access to the ballot has never been equal. Learn about the barriers faced during the suffragist movement.
It included just 28 words, but a single sentence transformed the civil rights of women in the United States. It was Article I of the 19th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution, and it guaranteed that ‚ÄúThe right of citizens of the United States to vote shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or by any State on account of sex.‚Äù Passed by Congress on June 4, 1919 and made into law in August 1920, the amendment gave women political power over 130 years after the nation‚Äôs founding.
It was the culmination o‚Ä¶

entry.title: 9 things to know about Holi, India‚Äôs most colorful festival
entry.summary:
A kaleidoscopic cloud hangs over India, where revellers mark the arrival of spring by throwing powdered dye with abandon, spraying water, and flooding the streets for raucous fun. Holi may be traditionally Hindu, but everyone is equal during this holiday. This year on March 14, color will hide all class lines, the caste system will disappear, and foreigners will join the locals.
Underneath the dancing and colorful chaos lies unique culture and deeply rooted tradition. Here‚Äôs what you need to know about Holi.
The colorful party makes up just one part of Holi. The night before, on Holika Dahan (the evening of bonfires), revelers set a symbolic effigy ablaze to commemorate the demise of the demoness Holika. People throw the famed, colored powder on Rangwali Holi, the second and mo‚Ä¶

ÊñáÁ´†Ê∑±ÂÖ•ÂàÜÊûê‰∫ÜÊ®°Âûã‰∏ä‰∏ãÊñáÂçèËÆÆ (MCP) Âø´ÈÄüÂ¥õËµ∑Âπ∂Êàê‰∏∫ AI Agent È¢ÜÂüüÂºÄÊîæÊ†áÂáÜÁöÑÂÖ≥ÈîÆÂõ†Á¥†„ÄÇ‰ΩúËÄÖËÆ§‰∏∫ÔºåMCP ÁöÑÊàêÂäüÂπ∂ÈùûÂÅ∂ÁÑ∂ÔºåËÄåÊòØÂæóÁõä‰∫éÂÖ∂‚ÄúAI ÂéüÁîü‚ÄùÁöÑËÆæËÆ°ÁêÜÂøµÔºåÂç≥ÂÖÖÂàÜËÄÉËôë‰∫Ü AI Agent ÁöÑÁã¨ÁâπÈúÄÊ±ÇÔºåÈíàÂØπÊÄßÂú∞Ëß£ÂÜ≥‰∫ÜÂä®ÊÄÅ‰∏ä‰∏ãÊñáËÆøÈóÆÁöÑÈóÆÈ¢òÔºåËøôÊòØ OpenAPI Á≠âÊ†áÂáÜÊú™ËÉΩÂÖÖÂàÜËß£ÂÜ≥ÁöÑ„ÄÇÊ≠§Â§ñÔºåAnthropic ‰Ωú‰∏∫ MCP ÁöÑÂº∫Â§ßÂêéÁõæÔºå‰ª•ÂèäÂÖ∂Âú®ÂºÄÂèëËÄÖÁæ§‰Ωì‰∏≠Âª∫Á´ãÁöÑËâØÂ•ΩÂìÅÁâåÂΩ¢Ë±°ÂíåÁ§æÂå∫Êé®ÂπøÔºå‰πü‰∏∫ MCP ÁöÑÊôÆÂèäÂ•†ÂÆö‰∫ÜÂü∫Á°Ä„ÄÇMCP ËøòÂÄüÈâ¥‰∫Ü LSP ÂçèËÆÆÁöÑÊàêÂäüÁªèÈ™åÔºåÂπ∂Êèê‰æõ‰∫ÜÂÆåÂñÑÁöÑÂ∑•ÂÖ∑ÈìæÂíå SDKÔºåÈôç‰Ωé‰∫ÜÂºÄÂèëËÄÖÁöÑ‰ΩøÁî®Èó®Êßõ„ÄÇÂ±ïÊúõÊú™Êù•ÔºåMCP ÊúâÊúõ‰∏éÂÖ∂‰ªñ AI ÊäÄÊúØËøõ‰∏ÄÊ≠•ËûçÂêàÔºåÊé®Âä® AI Agent ÁîüÊÄÅÁöÑÁπÅËç£ÂèëÂ±ï„ÄÇÊñáÁ´†ÊÄªÁªì‰∫Ü MCP ÊàêÂäüÁöÑÂÖ≥ÈîÆÂõ†Á¥†ÔºåÂπ∂ÂØπÊØîÂàÜÊûê‰∫ÜÂÖ∂‰ªñÁ´û‰∫âÊñπÊ°àÁöÑ‰∏çË∂≥‰πãÂ§ÑÔºå‰∏∫Êú™Êù•Ê†áÂáÜÂà∂ÂÆöÊèê‰æõ‰∫ÜÊúâÁõäÁöÑÂèÇËÄÉ„ÄÇ üí° ‰∏ªË¶ÅËßÇÁÇπ
MCP ÁöÑ‚ÄúAI ÂéüÁîü‚ÄùËÆæËÆ°ÔºåÈÄöËøáÂØπÂ∑•ÂÖ∑ (Tools)„ÄÅËµÑÊ∫ê (Resources) ÂíåÊèêÁ§∫ËØç (Prompts) ÁöÑÂå∫ÂàÜÔºåÊõ¥Á¨¶Âêà Agent ÂØπÂä®ÊÄÅ‰∏ä‰∏ãÊñáËÆøÈóÆÁöÑÈúÄÊ±Ç MCP ÂÖÖÂàÜËÄÉËôë‰∫Ü Agent ÂØπÂä®ÊÄÅ‰∏ä‰∏ãÊñáËÆøÈóÆÁöÑÈúÄÊ±ÇÔºåÂπ∂ÈíàÂØπÊÄßÂú∞Ëß£ÂÜ≥‰∫Ü‰º†ÁªüÊ†áÂáÜÈöæ‰ª•Ëß£ÂÜ≥ÁöÑÈóÆÈ¢òÔºå‰ªéËÄåÊèêÈ´ò‰∫ÜÂºÄÂèëÊïàÁéá„ÄÇ

entry.title: Where to taste the best of Vermont‚Äôs maple syrup
entry.summary:
It takes 40 gallons of tree sap to create one gallon of maple syrup. The formula might come from science, but the result is pure magic, especially to Vermonters, who‚Äôve been tapping and sugaring in the Green Mountains longer than the state‚Äôs existed.
The state‚Äôs sole outpost of IHOP, which closed in 2024, was the only branch in the country to serve real maple syrup. In part, this is because state law strictly prohibits labeling any product maple ‚Äî or even ‚Äúmaple flavored‚Äù ‚Äî if it doesn‚Äôt contain pure maple syrup. But more importantly, serving fake maple syrup would put a thumb in the eye of Vermont pride.¬†
As such, any traveler seeking the full Vermont experience must travel through maple country. And the closer you can get to the sugarhouse, the purer the experience. Visitor‚Ä¶

entry.title: What was Manhattan like in the Roaring Twenties? See for yourself
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
It‚Äôs been a century since The Great Gatsby was first published, shining a light on extravagant New York lifestyles in an era that went down in history as the ‚ÄòRoaring Twenties‚Äô. It was the decade that paved the way for Manhattan‚Äôs Chrysler Building and other progressive style icons, creating an anything-goes atmosphere for jazz-fuelled parties, Champagne afternoons and secret affairs in Prohibition speakeasies. And, 100 years later, it‚Äôs still possible to experience this defining spirit in one ultimate day out in New York City.
(It's the 100th anniversary of The Great Gatsby and New York is ready to party, old sport.)
Time travel back to 1922 with a hearty breakfast at the Square Diner, an original train-car‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to spend a week sailing around Greece's Ioanian islands
entry.summary:
Meganisi is renowned for its sea caves. A week aboard a yacht, with the help of a local skipper, makes for the ultimate sailing adventure around Greece‚Äôs Ionian Islands.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
‚ÄúReady to tack?‚Äù a voice shouts. Before I can ask what that means, the sails flicker and the entire boat suddenly tilts sideways. Dishes and bowls of fruit crash against each other inside the cabin. I grab hold of the railing and laugh nervously, but the smiles on my crewmates‚Äô faces reassure me that this is a good manoeuvre. Moments later, we catch the wind and we‚Äôre off. Apostolis Tsiokos, our tanned,silver-haired skipper, is humming along to We Are Sailing by Rod Stewart.
The 52ft monohull yacht, Neifinn, can accommodate up to 11 crew m‚Ä¶

entry.title: Women, girls bear brunt of cyberbullying against persons with disabilities
entry.summary: States must do more to prevent cyberbullying and overcome unequal access to assistive technology which hampers the rights of persons with disabilities - particularly women and girls - the Human Rights Council has heard.

entry.summary: Severe water shortages in Gaza have reached critical levels, with only one in 10 people currently able to access safe drinking water, the UN Children‚Äôs Fund (UNICEF) warned on Monday.

entry.summary: Gender equality is a critical goal at a time when the demand for rights faces a global backlash, top UN officials told thousands of diplomats, business and civil society delegates gathered at UN Headquarters in New York on Monday for the world‚Äôs largest annual conference focused on women‚Äôs issues.

entry.title: A practical guide to travelling in southern Mexico
entry.summary:
The historic centre of Oaxaca City is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. To get the best value, helpful booking tips and language lowdown, try this handy guide. 
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
¬†Central America is home to undisputed wonders. Its cultural attractions span ancient Maya sites, colourful 16th-century cities and Indigenous markets, while its landscapes cover active volcanoes, Caribbean beaches and tracts of jungle that are home to unique birds and big cats. Yet, for the most part, it's remained out of the international tourist trail, which means planning a first-time trip here can be somewhat intimidating.¬†¬†
The short answer is no. Without a visa, you can visit Belize for up to 30 days; Costa Rica for up to 180; and Panama ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why the way to travel Oaxaca's Pacific Coast is on two wheels
entry.summary:
Playa Zicatela is a world-renowned big-wave beach. A short stretch of Oaxaca‚Äôs scenic Pacific coast makes an easy day trip from Puerto Escondido ‚Äî plan on plenty of pit stops, whether you‚Äôre exploring via two wheels or four.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
There‚Äôs a word in Spanish, ‚Äòarrebol‚Äô, which doesn‚Äôt have a satisfactory English translation. It‚Äôs used to describe a crimson sunset, when each cloud on the horizon acquires a halo-like glow and the sky‚Äôs amber tint grows fainter as the sun slides into the sea. Such a sight would be a rarity in England, but on Mexico‚Äôs Pacific coast it‚Äôs a nightly occurrence. An arrebol accompanies bedtime on my first night in Puerto Escondido ‚Äî in this stylish party town, I‚Äôm probably the only person turnin‚Ä¶

entry.title: Maybe megalodon wasn‚Äôt so chonky after all
entry.summary:
This illustration of megalodon may be wrong. The ancient predatory shark went extinct around 3.6 million years ago and has been compared to modern great white sharks. However, new estimates suggest that megalodon had a slimmer, longer body.  A new study proposes that the massive ancient shark was built more slenderly than a great white. But not all paleontologists agree.
Close your eyes and imagine the ancient, abominable megalodon.
You‚Äôre probably picturing a great white shark scaled up to gargantuan proportions, right? Well, a new study suggests the world‚Äôs largest-ever shark may have been longer and more svelte than once thought.
‚ÄúPrevious studies simply assumed that megalodon must have looked like a gigantic version of the modern great white shark without any evi‚Ä¶

entry.title: Explainer: The Commission on the Status of Women and why it matters
entry.summary: Ever since former US First Lady and human rights champion Eleanor Roosevelt inspired the first UN sub-commission on the status of women in the 1940s, thousands of women around the world meet at UN Headquarters in New York every March to take the pulse of the planet and make their voices heard.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Ukraine reels from one of the deadliest days of war
entry.summary: Attacks across Ukraine on Friday reportedly left 21 civilians dead and scores injured, making it one of the deadliest days this year, the UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission in the country said in a statement issued on Saturday night.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN rights chief raises alarm over escalating violence in Syria
entry.summary: The killing of civilians in coastal areas in northwest Syria must cease immediately, the UN rights chief said on Sunday following a series of coordinated attacks reportedly launched by elements of the former government and other local armed men.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: A guide to ≈†ibenik, Croatia‚Äôs oldest coastal town
entry.summary:
On the central coastline of Dalmatia, where the River Krka winds its way to the Adriatic Sea, lies ≈†ibenik. For those in the know, the city provides a relaxed blend of history and natural beauty. It‚Äôs home to two UNESCO Heritage sites ‚Äî more than anywhere else in Croatia ‚Äî and has long attracted TV and film producers who have made use of its honeyed stone streets, grand old buildings and dramatic natural setting. Journey through ≈†ibenik‚Äôs history, explore dramatic fortresses and sample traditional Dalmatian cuisine on a city break here in 2025.¬†
While many other settlements on this stretch of coastline were founded by Romans, Greeks or other invading forces, ≈†ibenik was founded by Slavs at least as early as 1066 AD and, as such, is considered the oldest Croatian town on the Adriatic‚Ä¶

entry.title: 100 years after Gatsby, New York is reliving the Roaring Twenties
entry.summary:
The Chrysler Building‚Äôs spire is an iconic Art Deco addition to New York City's skyline. A hundred years after The Great Gatsby shone a light on extravagant Long Island mansions and secret speakeasies, the spirit of the Roaring Twenties is returning to New York.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
It‚Äôs late morning in Harlem and the jazz brunch at Minton‚Äôs Playhouse is in full swing. Cocktails are flying out across the polished mirrored bar, as up on stage a spotlit singer croons over an Ella Fitzgerald number. Behind her are framed photos of the jazz greats who once jammed at this legendary nightclub, including Billie Holiday and Dizzy Gillespie. To glance around the low-lit room, filled with chatter and jive, feels like stepping into New York‚Äôs‚Ä¶

entry.title: How female rappers are making their mark in America's Music City
entry.summary:
Rapper Mia Reona was raised in Nashville's African-American Jefferson Street district. In America‚Äôs country music capital, a new generation is stepping out from the shadows of its beloved honky-tonks. Meet the trailblazing female rappers singing ‚ÄòMusic City‚Äô a different song.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
It‚Äôs early evening in Nashville and classic country music drifts from the doorway of a nearby honky-tonk bar. Peeking inside the dingy dive, I see a four- piece band in matching western-wear owning the stage. Their rhinestone costumes dazzle under the spotlights as they serenade the crowd, who look amped for a night of serious two-stepping. For me it‚Äôs too early to start line dancing, so I continue strolling along Lower Broadway ‚Äî commonly‚Ä¶

entry.title: What's healthier: fresh or frozen produce?
entry.summary:
Despite the reputation frozen produce has for being unhealthy, studies show it's better than we think. Since frozen produce is picked and preserved at its peak, it can sometimes be considered more nutrient dense while also cutting down on food waste.
While frozen produce often gets a bad rap, research shows it can often be just as healthy‚Äîif not healthier‚Äîthan fresh produce.
In a study comparing the nutritional content of fresh and frozen corn, carrots, broccoli, spinach, peas, green beans, strawberries, and blueberries, researchers found that the vitamins in frozen produce are "comparable to and occasionally higher" than their fresh counterparts. Other studies have corroborated the idea that the only major nutritional difference between frozen and fresh produce is when refrig‚Ä¶

entry.title: Waterproof backpacks may be the perfect travel bags
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*¬†
A damp park map, a soaked granola bar, a fried laptop‚Äîthere‚Äôs nothing worse than water seeping into your travel gear. The only reliable way to keep your valuables dry in wet conditions is to store them in a waterproof‚Äîas opposed to a water-resistant‚Äîbackpack.¬†
‚ÄúWater-resistant‚Äù typically means the product‚Äôs exterior has been treated with a finish like Durable Water Repellent (DWR) coating. That offers partial protection from light rain or brief moi‚Ä¶

entry.title: A robot taught these birds a long-lost birdsong
entry.summary:
The song of the male chingolo, or rufous-collared sparrow (Zonotrichia capensis), is one of the most distinctive sounds in South America. In just a few seconds, this small bird‚Äîlight brown or whitish with black spots‚Äîdelivers its melody, composed of two to four introductory notes and a final trill. Each family of chingolos has its unique song, which they sing throughout their lives. But first, they must learn it.
This behavior is deeply rooted in the interaction between young and adult male chingolos, who transmit the patterns of their song. But what happens when this learning is interrupted‚Äîwhen habitat loss, population decline, or the disappearance of adult tutors break the chain of transmission?
(Huge decline in songbirds linked to common insecticide.)
Between 2020 and 20‚Ä¶

entry.title: Take a healing dip in UK's most historic spa towns
entry.summary:
Romans used Bath's hot spring to build a bathing complex in 43 CE. From local tribes worshipping a water goddess to Romans settling in areas with natural springs, England‚Äôs history of spa towns stretches further back than vacationing Victorians seeking to cure their ailments. Here‚Äôs how to explore some of the country‚Äôs most historic spa towns and experience the natural spring waters yourself.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Next time you swig some British spring water, take a moment to ponder where it came from ‚Äî maybe Harrogate, Malvern or Buxton? From the late 1700s, English towns with nearby springs were transformed into spa destinations, becoming magnets for those who believed these waters could cure everything from scabies to smallpox. entry.title: The unexpected wine country you need to visit: New Mexico
entry.summary:
The Rio Grande Valley is one of New Mexico‚Äôs most prolific winemaking regions. Hispanic and Native American wine producers cultivate vineyards at high altitude and on desert plains in this southwestern state, making for some unique cellar-door visits.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Framed by the Sangre de Cristo Mountains in the north and the Chihuahuan Desert in the south, the US‚Äôs fifth-largest state is a land of rolling sand dunes, prehistoric petroglyphs, fairytale caves and dormant volcanoes. Equally as diverse as the topography is the culture, which reflects the history of the Indigenous, Hispanics and Anglo Americans who have coexisted in New Mexico for centuries. You‚Äôre most likely to first encounter this diversity through the cuisi‚Ä¶

entry.title: Where to travel in April
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK)
April is the month where there's all to play for. The Med is back in action for sun and coastal fun, putting short-haul escapes to the beaches within easy reach once again, while the last of the Alpine snow keeps winter sports lovers entertained for just a bit longer. In most resorts across the Alps, the ski season closes this month, with some high-octane, high-altitude festivals to see it out ‚Äî among them Zermatt Unplugged in Switzerland, which brings nearly 70 different artists to the mountains.
Further afield, Thai new year celebrations see its cities making a splash, Coachella kicks off the summer's music festivals out in the California desert and travel is enriched by Easter celebrations worldwide.
In more‚Ä¶

entry.title: Do dogs hate daylight saving time too?
entry.summary:
With daylight saving time starting this month, dogs and their owners will likely lose an hour of sleep, as clocks are set forward. And if you‚Äôve ever wondered if domesticated dogs have as much trouble adjusting to the time change as humans do, it turns out, scientists have looked into this question.
¬†In 2021, researchers in Ontario, Canada, conducted a study of both sled dogs and companion dogs during fall daylight saving time, when we gain an hour and see an earlier sunrise. Both dogs and their human owners or caretakers wore sensors (on their collars and wrists, respectively), which measured movement and activity.¬†¬†
The scientists found while the pets had no trouble with the change, it took the sled dogs‚Äîworking canines who were housed outdoors in kennels‚Äîa day to adjust.¬†This ‚Ä¶

entry.title: 10 family-friendly things to do in Texas
entry.summary:
Visitors enjoy a star party at the McDonald Observatory in Fort Davis, Texas. It‚Äôs just one of 10 things families should add to their kid-friendly itinerary when visiting the Lone Star State. Feel tiny under the big Texas sky, marvel at an annual bat migration, travel on horseback through a colorful canyon, and soak in sublime hot springs.
Larger than any country in Western Europe, Texas sprawls across more than 268,000 square miles that touch Mexico, the Gulf of Mexico, and four U.S. states. The Lone Star State is so vast and diverse in its landscapes and cultures that it can feel like a wondrous country all its own. Wherever you land to kick off your family adventures here‚Äîwhether an urban metropolis like Dallas-Fort Worth, Houston, or Austin, or somewhere altogether more off the‚Ä¶

entry.title: 10 family-friendly hotels in Texas
entry.summary:
Families visiting Dinosaur Valley State Park in Glen Rose should consider staying nearby at the hotel, La Palmilla. It‚Äôs just one of 10 recommended family-friendly hotels to stay when visiting Texas.  Looking for a hotel that keeps both adults and kids in mind? These options across the state offer on-site water parks and bike trails, or easy access to nearby river cruises and dinosaur tracks.
Interactive museums and street art. Hiking and horseback riding. Dinosaur tracks and early settlements. These Texas hotels give adults and kids easy access to all the state has to offer. And with on-site pools, tennis courts, and even TopGolf simulators, it‚Äôs more than okay to just hang out on the property, too.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†
Overlooking the famous River Walk, the 338-room, Spanish Coloni‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why it‚Äôs unlikely Mount Vesuvius really turned a brain to glass
entry.summary:
In the ruins of Herculaneum, an Ancient Roman city on the west coast of Italy that was buried by Mount Vesuvius's catastrophic eruption in 79 A.D., researchers made a startling discovery: a human brain transformed into glass. It was the first documented case of a brain naturally preserved in such a shocking state.¬†
The remains were found inside the skull of a seemingly male victim lying in a charred bed within¬†the Collegium Augustalium, preserved in what the researchers describe as an "obsidian-like" material with a black, shiny appearance.¬†
But exactly how the eruption would have caused such an unprecedented transformation remained a mystery when the ancient victim was found.
Now, the same scientists who discovered this glass, have published a study in Scientific Reports sa‚Ä¶

entry.title: Millions in Central Sahel and Nigeria face food cuts amid WFP funding crisis
entry.summary: The UN World Food Programme (WFP) warned on Friday that potentially life-saving food and nutrition assistance in Central Sahel and Nigeria will have to end next month, unless emergency funds can be secured.

entry.title: Post-Assad Syria faces critical test over eliminating chemical weapons
entry.summary: The fall of the Assad regime has created a historic opportunity to rid Syria of chemical weapons and ensure long-term compliance with the Chemical Weapons Convention (CWC), the UN‚Äôs top disarmament official told the Security Council on Friday.

entry.title: Syria: Up to one million people plan to return home in desperation
entry.summary: Up to one million desperate Syrians living in camps and displacement sites across the country‚Äôs northwest intend to return home within the next year ‚Äì sparking deep concerns of a new humanitarian crisis.

entry.title: DR Congo crisis leaves mothers with newborns fleeing to Burundi
entry.summary: The aid response in Burundi to the crisis in neighbouring Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) ‚Äúis literally buckling‚Äù, the UN refugee agency, UNHCR, warned on Friday, as it relayed dramatic testimonies from people forced to flee the unchecked advance of Rwanda-backed M23 rebels.

entry.summary: A decline in democracy and harmful content spread on social media platforms are helping to drive a backlash against feminism, and the growth of misogynistic and retrograde ideas about the roles of men and women and society.

entry.title: The hidden meaning behind Rome's famous arch monuments
entry.summary:
Temples functioned as sites of worship, and the Colosseum served as an amphitheater for games and spectacles. But triumphal arches‚Äîsuch as the Arch of Constantine‚Äîwere remarkable for being among the few purely symbolic buildings erected by the Romans. With their decorative sculptures, reliefs, and inscriptions, these monuments provide a wealth of historical sources to researchers, and their excellent state of preservation has secured them pride of place in the collective memory of many generations of scholars, travelers, and politicians interested in the ancient Roman Empire.
The triumphal arch originally grew out of the triumphal parade, a ceremony integral to life in the Roman Republic. These lavish processions through Rome were a way for generals and their soldiers to celebrate the‚Ä¶

entry.title: The best wineries on the Gran Canaria Wine Route
entry.summary: Gran Canaria might not be the first place you think of when it comes to wine, but vines have been growing here since the Spanish colonised the island in the 15th century. Due to the island's distinctive microclimate and volcanic soils, grapes grow incredibly well, and the Canarian archipelago lays claim to 18 unique grape varieties, including the famous Malvas√≠a Arom√°tica ‚Äî featured in some of Shakespeare‚Äôs famous works. Though red varieties make up about 70% of Gran Canaria's wine production, connoisseurs should keep an eye out for local white, ros√©, sparkling and sweet wines, too. The best way to sample them? By taking to the trail on the Gran Canaria Wine Route ‚Äî the only official wine route in the Canary Islands ‚Äî which includes vineyards, bodegas, bars and restaurants that produce or ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Hoping to ski until July? Here are 7 places to go in the U.S.
entry.summary:
At Alyeska Resort in Alaska, the northern lights can sometimes be seen through April. These resorts keep the lifts spinning late into the season, providing access to some of the best spring‚Äîand summer‚Äîskiing in North America.
It is typical to crave a tropical destination when trying to survive the last few months of winter, but skiers know that springtime is the best-kept secret in the sport.
With fewer crowds, soft snow, and long apr√®s-ski afternoons spent in the sunshine, this is the best time of year to be on the mountain. The intensity of chasing mid-winter powder days has subsided, and the celebratory spring atmosphere brings a new energy.
Pack your sunscreen and warm-weather wax and get ready to enjoy the last few turns of the season. From longtime skiers to familie‚Ä¶

entry.title: 1 in 5 butterflies in the U.S. have disappeared
entry.summary:
Researchers compiled data on more than five hundred butterfly species across the United States from 2000 to 2020. Some species are faring better than others, but overall, butterfly numbers dropped by 22 percent.  Researchers identified over 100 species that have dropped by more than 50 percent in the last two decades: "This is a wake-up call."
In the last 20 years, one in five butterflies have disappeared in the United States.
According to a landmark study published today in the journal Science, total butterfly abundance in the U.S. has declined by 22 percent across all species between 2000 and 2020.¬†
‚ÄúThis is a wake-up call. People should be seeing this number and being very, very concerned, not just about butterflies, but about the state of insects in general,‚Ä¶

entry.title: Darwin couldn't find these fabled horses. They've reappeared.
entry.summary:
A genetic mutation causes the Argentine Criollo horse to grow curly hair. The mysterious curly coated horses in South America evaded the famed naturalist. But now one couple is forming a herd of their own‚Äîand trying to save the species.
There, in a desolate corner of the Somuncur√° Plateau in the Argentine province of R√≠o Negro‚Äîwhere the word ‚Äúinhospitable‚Äù seems to have been invented‚ÄîGerardo Rodr√≠guez, a veterinarian, spotted a horse calmly grazing amid the rugged landscape. Seeing any horse in such an isolated, arid region was already unusual, but this one was unlike anything he had ever encountered: Its coat was curly.
Initially, Rodr√≠guez thought the horse‚Äôs curly coat indicated it was sick or sweaty, but a gaucho, or horseman, told him something surprising: These curly-hai‚Ä¶

entry.title: Where to try the food on ‚ÄòNo Taste Like Home with Antoni Porowski‚Äô
entry.summary: Actress Issa Rae and No Taste Like Home host Antoni Porowski sit with Mama Yacine, Fatima Fall, Papa Abdoulaye Sene, and Hamade Ndiaye to eat ceebu j√´n, also known as thieboudienne, a Senegalese dish made with fish, rice, and tomato sauce. These traditional family recipes each tell a story about ancestral heritage. Here's how you can try each one‚Äîfrom tortellini en brodo in Italy to jajangmyeon in South Korea. In¬†National Geographic‚Äôs¬†series¬†No Taste Like Home with Antoni Porowski, six Hollywood stars follow the Queer Eye star on a journey through food and time as they travel through their ancestral homelands in search of family history. Starting with just one homemade family recipe, Porowski helps stars Awkwafina, Justin Theroux, Issa Rae, ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Follow in Malcolm X's footsteps on a civil rights history tour in Boston
entry.summary:
West Acorn Street in Beacon Hill takes travellers along the Black Heritage Trail. It‚Äôs 100 years since the civil rights activist was born. Follow in his footsteps on a tour of Boston‚Äôs suburbs, where his legacy lives on.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Malcolm X‚Äôs birthday will be recognised as a new annual holiday in Boston this May. Though born in Nebraska in 1925, the civil rights activist lived in the Massachusetts city on and off for 12 years during a pivotal ‚Äî if controversial ‚Äî era in the fight for African American rights in the US. The formative years he spent in Boston ‚Äî becoming a leading Muslim minister here before his assassination at a New York rally in 1965 ‚Äî have left a lasting legacy that can still be seen in the city‚Äôs monume‚Ä¶

entry.title: 10 of the best hotels in Salzburg, Austria
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The most Austrian of cities, Salzburg is an instant heart-stealer. It‚Äôs¬†backdropped by the M√∂nchsberg, a mount rising like a gentle giant above the old town‚Äôs alleys and abbeys, plazas and palaces. Topping it is a 900-year-old fortress straight out of a kids‚Äô story, while the mountains on the horizon remind you that the Alps are but a yodel away. The hotel scene mirrors the city itself: petite, characterful and surprisingly varied, skipping from revamped medieval inns to affordable palace stays. If you‚Äôre visiting, book now: in 2025, Salzburg will celebrate 60 years of The Sound of Music with performances, exhibitions and tours of filming locations. Rooms in Hotel Schloss M√∂nchstein hold an antique and whimsical c‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why This Colombian Investigative Reporter Had to Wait Over a Decade to Tell a Story
entry.summary: Ginna Morelo put part of her investigation into Colombian paramilitaries on hold for 13 years to protect her family and sources. She tells how she decided it was finally time to publish.

entry.title: I‚Äôm a stroke survivor. These tools make travel easier.
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*¬†
I love exploring new places and enjoying adventures with family and friends. However, as a stroke survivor with autoimmune diseases as well as assorted back and leg issues, mobility considerations‚Äîsometimes accompanied by muscle aches and/or joint pain‚Äîare a part of my daily life. I also experience frequent vertigo that can make me lose my balance or fall. These are all factors I must consider when planning a trip.¬†¬†

entry.title: Why March is Women's History Month in the U.S.
entry.summary:
Women have always been part of history. But for centuries, their participation in it was overlooked: Early history texts often excluded women altogether, aside from accounts of powerful women like queens. Historians‚Äîwho were almost entirely men‚Äîoften saw the past through the lens of the ‚Äúgreat man‚Äù theory, which holds that history is largely shaped by male heroes and their struggles.
That changed in the 20th century, with the birth of women‚Äôs history as an academic discipline, a push to recognize the achievements of women‚Äîand a movement to ensure women had equal access to the academic institutions where their history might be taught. In the United States, the result was National Women‚Äôs History Month, an annual celebration born from the activism of historians intent on making sure wom‚Ä¶

Code execution gives Gemini models access to a Python sandboxÔºå allowing them to run code and learn from the results. Code execution enabledÔºå Gemini models can perform calculationsÔºå analyze complex data setsÔºå and create visualizations on the fly - ultimately providing better answers to user queries. entry.title: The best way to experience Alpine culture? Eat‚Äîand drink‚Äîit
entry.summary:
Harsh temperatures and unpredictable high-altitude soil have strengthened the roots of the Alps, and the farmers living there are as resilient as the food they grow. Here, people have survived the unimaginable: In 1916, more than 200 Austro-Hungarian World War I soldiers lived at 12,000 feet for a year inside Italy‚Äôs Marmolada Glacier, in a city of ice tunnels they dug by hand, rationing bread and meat, and, when they could get it, a soft sweet bundt cake called gugelhupf to ease their pain.
Those hidden ice trenches are now the site of another slow battle: Climate change is expected to melt the glacier completely by 2040.
Through thick and thin ‚Äî traversing dangerous mountain passes in winter storms, avalanches, and in the face of climate change ‚Äî lives in the Alps have depended‚Ä¶

entry.title: 10 lizards came to Cincinnati in a sock. Now there are thousands.
entry.summary:
A Lazarus lizard suns itself on a warm rock in Burnet Woods, one of many European transplants that have taken over Cincinnati, Ohio. Scientists say the city‚Äôs hills, aging infrastructure, and even its climate have helped them thrive. Native to Europe, common wall lizards are growing bigger, faster, and more resilient in Ohio. Scientists say the city itself may be driving their evolution.
For more than 70 years, thousands of common wall lizards, known as Lazarus lizards, from Europe have made Cincinnati their home. Even through record-low temperatures and snowfall, they‚Äôve managed to survive‚Äîand multiply. But how did these Mediterranean reptiles gain such a foothold in a Midwestern city? It all started with a 10-year-old boy and a sock full of lizards.
In 1951, George Rau Jr., ‚Ä¶

entry.title: What are menopause retreats and how do they help?
entry.summary:
The Preidlhof Garden Spa offers nature-inspired treatments. The transformative journey of menopause is finally stepping into the spotlight, with specialised retreats offering tailored support to nurture both body and mind during this pivotal phase.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Menopause and perimenopause were once topics shrouded in silence, leaving women to navigate the physical and emotional challenges alone. Today, thanks to trailblazers like Davina McCall, awareness has surged, with women openly sharing their experiences, healthcare professionals taking a more proactive approach and workplaces offering menopause training. This shift marks a new era of support and understanding for women during this crucial life stage, and has led to th‚Ä¶

entry.title: Scientists find a new titanosaur dinosaur species in Patagonia
entry.summary:
Hundreds of fossils found at a quarry in Northern Patagonia provide a snapshot of what a desert pond ecosystem might have looked like in the late Cretaceous period. Researchers found a previously undiscovered species of titanosaur (illustrated above) among other fossilized creatures at the site.  The new Argentine dino might give us clues to what the world was like before the asteroid wiped out their kind.
In Northern Patagonia, paleontologists have unearthed an ancient lagoon ecosystem surrounded by sand dunes and palm trees where prehistoric creatures thrived. Excavations of 78 million year-old rocks, from a quarry just outside General Roca city in Argentina, yielded a treasure trove of 432 fossils belonging to over a hundred animal groups.
The majority of the‚Ä¶

entry.title: Meet the Maya artisans of Lake Atitl√°n
entry.summary:
One of many myths surrounding Lake Atitl√°n tells of an ancient Maya sorceress who forged a magic ring for a Spanish conquistador, swearing it would make him irresistible to the object of his affection. Long story short: the plan went sideways, and the ring was lost at the bottom of the lake. There it remains, they say, still casting its spell through the water like an electric current, drawing travellers to these shores and compelling them to fall in love with the place.
It worked on the hippies, who drifted this way in the 1960s, when word spread of a spectacular lake with mystical powers in west-central Guatemala. It works on contemporary wellness enthusiasts, who now sustain an industry of yoga retreats, thermal spas and ‚Äòpsychic development‚Äô courses. And it works on me, too ‚Äî thou‚Ä¶

entry.title: Does slurping or loud chewing enrage you? You may have misophonia.
entry.summary:
For those with misophonia, everyday sounds like slurping or chewing can trigger a fight-or-flight response. Scientists are working to understand why. For people with misophonia, the sound of chewing, tapping, or sniffing isn‚Äôt just annoying‚Äîit‚Äôs unbearable. Scientists are unraveling the mystery behind this little-known condition and how to treat it.
Everyone gets annoyed by certain noises at times. You might wince at the screech of feedback from a microphone or want to scream at the construction worker pummeling a pneumatic drill outside your window. But for some people, the quietest sounds are the most excruciating.
For people with misophonia, every day sounds like slurping, tapping, or sniffing don‚Äôt just annoy‚Äîthey trigger an intense fight-or-flight response. The condition,‚Ä¶

entry.title: The secret to a healthy gut is simpler than you think
entry.summary:
One of the secrets to better gut health is simpler than you might think: Eating a wide variety of plants helps a wide variety of beneficial bacteria flourish in your gut microbiome, according to a large study published in the journal Nature Microbiology. And it‚Äôs still good for you even if you occasionally enjoy meat, which is otherwise¬†linked to more ‚Äúbad‚Äù bacteria.
For the study, more than 21,000 people in the United States, United Kingdom, and Italy used an app to answer detailed questionnaires about what they ate on a regular basis. Their diets were grouped into three buckets: omnivore (including meat, dairy, and plants), vegetarian (no meat), or vegan (no animal products).
The researchers used DNA technology to analyze participants‚Äô stool samples, which allowed them to ident‚Ä¶

entry.title: The internet‚Äôs favorite bald eagles just had hatchlings
entry.summary:
Shadow the bald eagle stands guard over three eggs in his nest atop a 145-foot tree in Big Bear Lake Forest in California. Shadow and his mate Jackie have become internet sensations thanks to a nest cam that documents their daily lives. After losing their chicks for the past two years, these famous bird parents finally got some good news at long last.
Jackie and Shadow, a beloved bald eagle pair in Big Bear Lake Forest, a hundred miles northeast of Los Angeles, welcomed two new chicks into the world, one at around 4 a.m. on March 4 and the other at 11:36 p.m. on March 3. The world is still waiting to see if another eaglet emerges from the couple‚Äôs third egg.
"So, all of us are just crying tears of joy for eagle babies in the middle of the night?" commented one Facebook user on‚Ä¶

entry.title: Scientists may finally know why starlings form mesmerizing clouds
entry.summary:
A convergence of starlings swirls above St. Peter‚Äôs Basilica in Rome. For centuries, researchers have pondered how starlings travel in those gorgeous shape-shifting clouds. The answers continue to surprise them.
On winter evenings¬†throughout much of Europe and North America, an hour before sunset, thousands of starlings gather in the skies. Before descending to their nighttime roosts, the birds put on one of nature‚Äôs most spectacular displays. They pulse, ripple, and wheel as if they were a single entity‚Äîan amorphous, shape-shifting creature with the delicate beauty of calligraphic brushstrokes and the erratic chaos of flickering flames.
How could so many birds be so tightly coordinated? That‚Äôs a mystery that researchers have sought to solve for more than a century. In 1931, t‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to plan the ultimate adventure through Southern Mexico
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
A region of small-hold farms and understated towns, Mexico‚Äôs southern states remain truest to the country‚Äôs Indigenous roots. There are settlements here that have endured for more than 5,000 years. Those who visit the vast valleys of Oaxaca and the jungles of Chiapas today can glimpse authentic insights into the day-to-day lives of their first peoples.
Both Oaxaca and Chiapas were distinct centres of civilisation long before the Aztec Empire arose in central Mexico around 1300 CE. Each sustained its own grand, hidden city ‚Äî Oaxaca‚Äôs mountaintop Monte Alb√°n flourished from 500 BCE to 850 CE, while Chiapas‚Äôs forest-shrouded Palenque was at its height in the sixth and seventh centuries CE.
The influence of each ‚Ä¶

entry.title: 6 of the best places to eat and drink in Lyon
entry.summary:
From Michelin-starred restaurants to cosy bistros, discover Lyon's superb gastronomy by eating your way around the city.
Positioned at the crossroads of Burgundy and the Rhone Valley, Lyon has long occupied a position of culinary privilege. Its chefs are spoiled by superior produce drawn from the local area, including wines from the vineyards of Beaujolais and cheeses and meats from the foothills of the Alps. In the city, restaurant offerings range from high-level classic French cuisine to international fusion concepts brought here by creative chefs from around the world. Whatever you fancy eating, you‚Äôll find it in Lyon ‚Äî just be sure to bring a big appetite.
The narrow streets of Vieux Lyon are a maze of Renaissance buildings, secret passageways and beautiful courtyards. ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Flying in 2025? Here‚Äôs how to find the cheapest flights
entry.summary:
Flight alerts help travelers track fluctuating prices, so you know when your ideal flight drops in cost. From myth-busting outdated tips to the best search tools, travel experts weigh in on how to find affordable airfare.
Booking affordable airfare can be a turbulent process. Prices rise and fall day by day, or in some cases, hour by hour. In the past, frequent fliers swore by loose strategies to find deals ‚Äî book on a Tuesday! No, on a Wednesday! Never on a weekend! ‚Äî but experts caution that many suggestions don‚Äôt amount to more than myth.
While finding cheap airfare might feel futile, it‚Äôs not impossible. Here‚Äôs what experts say you need to know.
If you're looking for a cross-country flight this summer, you'll notice that the prices tend to go up and down. One day, i‚Ä¶

entry.title: What we know about the mysterious illness in the DRC
entry.summary:
Colored transmission electron micrograph (TEM) of a human red blood cell (red) infected with the malarial parasite Plasmodium sp. (blue). Malaria is one of several suspected culprits of this outbreak, as it was revealed as the cause of another mystery disease outbreak in the DRC at the end of 2024. The unidentified ailment has sickened 1,300 people and led to more than 50 deaths. Regardless of the cause, experts say containing the outbreak will be challenging.
  Over the past month, an unidentified illness has sickened more than 1,300 people and led to more than 50 deaths in the northwestern part of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). entry.title: The lost homes of enslaved Africans may be hidden in their bones
entry.summary:
Strontium is an alkaline earth metal that is soft, silvery-white and turns yellow when exposed to air‚Äîit's often used in fireworks for this reason. It also shows up in bedrock, so researchers are using the element to help trace the roots of ancestors forcibly displaced by the transatlantic slave trade. Scientists have created a groundbreaking map of strontium isotopes found across sub-Saharan Africa‚Äîwhich could help descendants of enslaved people reconstruct their family histories.
‚ÄúWhere were my ancestors?‚Äù is a question that‚Äôs followed Andre Kearns for as long as he can remember. He still recalls his middle school geography assignment to color in a map of New York City with the different ethnic enclaves at the turn of the 20th century. When Kearns began to shade in a Black neighb‚Ä¶

Whether you‚Äôre traveling or updating your wardrobe, the best spring jacket should be a multitasker.¬†¬†

entry.title: Bone pit hints at human, animal sacrifice in Roman-era Britain
entry.summary:
Dead puppies, potential human sacrifices and a painted dog penis bone buried in a ritual deposit in an ancient quarry shaft in southern England are revealing what fertility rituals may have looked like in the early decades of Roman conquest.
‚ÄúIt was filled with an absolutely shocking number of bones,‚Äù says Ellen Green, a bioarchaeologist at the University of Reading. ‚ÄúYou couldn‚Äôt move around in there without stepping on something.‚Äù Green describes the find in a recent issue of the Oxford Journal of Archaeology.¬†
The hole full of bones‚Äîthe largest ritual deposit discovered of its kind dating to the Roman Britain period‚Äîgives archaeologists hints about the ways that conquered British did‚Äîand didn‚Äôt‚Äîadopt the cultural practices of Rome as early as the first century A.D.
Gree‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to experience Carnival in the Caribbean
entry.summary:
In Barbados, Grand Kadooment Day is traditionally held on the first Monday in August every year to mark the end of the six-week celebration, Crop Over, and the end of the sugarcane harvest. More than just a party, Carnival is a tradition steeped in history. We delve into unique celebrations across the islands, from stickfighting and chipping in Trinidad to Junkanoo in the Bahamas.
More than two dozen countries make up the Caribbean, each with its own vernacular, history, food, and culture. Despite these distinctions, one tradition connects every island‚ÄîCarnival. Born from the ingenuity of enslaved African people determined to survive in the face of brutality, the tradition has survived over the years with much of the same song, dance, and even mockery that were integral parts of i‚Ä¶

entry.title: Can guys and girls really just be friends? Ask these baboons.
entry.summary:
A young Kinda baboon at Mahale Mountains Nationalpark, Tansania. A new study found this species of baboon forms long term male and female friendships. These friendships often lasted for life, and scientists say they show how male primates can use kindness and affection to socially succeed.
Observing the same group of wild baboons for over a decade, primatologist Anna Weyher says their individual personalities begin to stand out. One baboon named Simon was a good father, a ‚Äúnice guy‚Äù to female baboons, while his brother Garfunkel was ‚Äúmore grumpy.‚Äù¬†
‚ÄúOver time you get to know them so well,‚Äù says Weyher.¬†¬†
After observing Kinda baboons (Papio kindae) in Zambia‚Äôs Kasanka National Park for nine years, Weyher‚Äôs research team published their findings in January, the first long‚Ä¶

entry.title: A neighbourhood guide to Copenhagen
entry.summary:
Copenhagen may be a compact city ‚Äî¬†you can cycle from one side to the other in about 15 minutes ‚Äî¬†but it‚Äôs built upon a vibrant patchwork of distinct, characterful neighbourhoods. Depending on where you stay, you may find yourself surrounded by innovative new builds, trendy brewpubs or contemporary art spaces, each one offering a different way of experiencing the city. Here, we take a look at some of the city's most intriguing neighbourhoods ‚Äî from Christianshavn's historic, colourful streets to the inventive modern architecture of Nordhavn. Take some time to explore and decide which is the one for you.
For independent shops and cafes Known for being the city‚Äôs former red-light district, Vesterbro has cleaned up its act and is now full of independent shops, vintage boutiques and cas‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why northern Portugal should be your next road trip destination
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Of all the seasons in Portugal, summer is the longest and most beloved, with warm days crowned by burnished sunsets reaching well into the harvest months. In the busy cities and beach towns of the country‚Äôs south, it can be easy to deny the subtle shifts in the landscape that signal the tiptoe into autumn. But in the country‚Äôs untamed north, the scenery demands to be read: amber grapes swell on trellised vines, chestnut groves pound the earth with their fruit and fat mushrooms bloom in forests simmering with golden leaves. The signs are unmistakable on my drive from Porto to the hamlet of Amares, in the depths of the Minho region.
Yet perhaps I still have summer on my mind as I launch myself from a meadow bank into‚Ä¶

To help, we asked active women who spend lots of time in a swimsuit to share their top picks and tips. They may spend more time in bathing suits than most, but their concerns are similar to that of most women. We all want to look ‚Ä¶

entry.title: See how the spice trade legacy continues to shape Kochi, India
entry.summary:
Kochi's inhabitants carry great pride in their spice-infused history. Gateway to the canals and lagoons of the Kerala backwaters and to the Arabian Sea, Kochi was for centuries a major hub for the spice trade. This legacy has left an indelible mark on its identity and continues to shape the multilayered city today.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK). undefined undefined The backwaters can be just as colourful, with garlands of marigolds hung over the sides of boats. Representing the sun and symbolising brightness and auspiciousness, marigolds are often used during celebrations and as offerings throughout India. Kerala‚Äôs backwaters run parallel to the Arabian Sea, stretching north and south of Kochi. They‚Äôre home to plantations growing a variety of spices such as cloves, nutmeg, cardamom, cinnamon and turmeric. Fruits including bananas, coconuts and mangoes also thrive here. Life on the plantations is dictated by the rhythms of nature and the changing seasons. Published in the March 2025 issue of National Geographic Traveller (UK). To subscribe to¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK) magazine click here. (Available in select countries only).

entry.title: 15 of the best UK destinations for spring travel
entry.summary:
Tintern Abbey is a 13th-century gothic masterpiece sitting beside the River Wye in southeast Wales. From the Yorkshire moors to the Cornish seaside, these alluring spots make for a classic British holiday.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Whether you‚Äôre longing to fill your lungs with sea air or are looking to spend some quiet days rambling through the countryside, these UK destinations are all perfectly suited to spring travel. From the ‚ÄòQueen of Welsh resorts‚Äô to the region that‚Äôs home to the UK‚Äôs rarest butterfly species, these are 15 of the best destinations to escape to this Easter holiday and beyond.
The West Midlands county of Staffordshire was once a powerhouse of innovation, taking 18th-century¬†Britain¬†into a ground-breaking fu‚Ä¶

entry.title: Rediscover real island living
entry.summary:
White sand, blush-pink granite boulders, and verdant coastal forest define the inner islands of Seychelles. Untouched until the 18th century, Seychelles is a remarkable place of pristine natural beauty. This nation of granitic and coralline isles scattered in the Indian Ocean redefines the idea of an island escape.
There are many places that call themselves paradise, but Seychelles, near-equatorial islands strung like emeralds through the turquoise blues of the remote western Indian Ocean, surely claims the crown. A hotbed of biodiversity, these coral-fringed, jungle-clad isles were spotted by the Portuguese explorer Vasco da Gama in 1502, but the first Europeans to set foot here were British‚Äîrepresentatives of the British East India Company in 1609. Yet Seychelles remained unsettl‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why there's never been a better time to travel with your pets
entry.summary:
Many hotels across the globe, such as The Hoxton in Southwark, London, now cater for travellers with pets. More people are travelling with their animal than ever. Here‚Äôs what you need to know from how to fly with your dog to the latest pet-focused services.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
New statistics have highlighted the rising demand for pet-friendly travel experiences. The 2024 Annual Vacation Confidence Index by Allianz Partners USA found that over 40% of US travellers aged 34-54 years old will include their pets on their next holiday, with 24% of those over 55 doing the same.
Several travel companies in the UK have reported a rise in pet-friendly bookings over the past couple of years. Dog-friendly accommodation site Paws & Stay ‚Ä¶

entry.title: America‚Äôs original vacation hotspot is making a comeback
entry.summary:
Lake Placid and Whiteface Mountain is a famous sight of the Adirondacks. The American vacation was born in the Adirondack Mountains ‚Äî and now this remote region is experiencing a revival.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Rowing cross-handed takes some getting used to, but that‚Äôs the technique required to master an Adirondack guide boat ‚Äî the lightweight yet sturdy wooden vessel built for the rugged waterways of northern New York State. After a knuckle-bashing start with its long oars, I‚Äôm soon gliding across the glassy surface of Sagamore Lake. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre rewiring your brain right now,‚Äù says my guide, Cari Ray. ‚ÄúDoesn‚Äôt that feel good?‚Äù
The plaintive calls of a solitary loon echo across the water, but aside from this bird we‚Äôre alone on th‚Ä¶

entry.title: The harrowing history behind 'I'm Still Here'
entry.summary:
On a hot January morning in 1971, plainclothes security agents knocked on the door of the beachfront home of former Brazilian lawmaker Rubens Paiva. Hustled into his car, Paiva was sped away under armed escort and never seen again, leaving his wife and five children to pick up the pieces. This is the broad plotline of I‚Äôm Still Here, the Oscar-winning film set during Brazilian military rule. But rather than dwell on the dictators‚Äô dungeons and the all too visceral horrors of state-sponsored violence, director Walter Salles flips the narrative.
Instead, the film pivots to Paiva‚Äôs wife, then widow, Eunice, as she relentlessly presses an obtuse military junta for justice over the next five decades, even as she struggles to provide for a fractured family. It‚Äôs an intimate window on Brazil‚Ä¶

entry.title: 7 luxurious hotels you can feel good about checking into
entry.summary:
Populas in Denver, Colorado, is a carbon-positive hotel, meaning that it aims to reduce more carbon than it creates. From a new purpose-driven safari in South Africa to a carbon-positive hotel in the United States, here‚Äôs how to turn your next stay into a force for good.
Travel trends come and go, but when it comes to sustainability, these hotels are all in.
‚ÄúBy choosing accommodation providers with strong sustainability practices, such as those supporting local conservation efforts or engaging in community initiatives, travelers can ensure their stays align with their personal values while positively impacting the environment and the communities they visit,‚Äù says Sally Davey, CEO of sustainable travel organization Travalyst.
Davey, who also works in collaboration with th‚Ä¶

entry.title: Deadly wildfires are making their way east
entry.summary:
Two men spray water on a raging fire as it threatens homes in Conway, South Carolina. Wildfires may be more common in the West but could deadlier in the East where they're more likely to burn through homes and businesses.  We all know wildfires have been getting worse in the drought-stricken western U.S., but experts say the growing risk on the east coast is concerning.
When we think of wildfires, we often think of western states like California where massive blazes, such as the fires that burned in and around Los Angeles earlier this year. But more than 100 fires recently burned through North and South Carolina amid dry and windy conditions.
While California and other western states face a high wildfire risk, the west is less densely populated and fires often arise in t‚Ä¶

Whether you‚Äôre facing sudden showers or chilly breezes while traveling in the spring, a reliable, lightweight jacket is an essential part of any packing list.¬†
‚ÄúLook for something you can wear year-round,‚Äù says Justin Shachter, a NASA engineer and an outdoor enthusiast based in Los Angeles, California. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll want to be protected during a 70-degree day, yet warm enough if it gets down to 45 or 50.‚Äù¬†
‚ÄúI‚Äôm looking for something water resistant.‚Ä¶

entry.title: The meaning of the cross of ashes on Ash Wednesday
entry.summary:
A woman with a cross of ashes on her forehead attends a traditional Ash Wednesday service at the Metropolitan Cathedral in San Jose, Costa Rica. The Christian holiday marks the start of Lent, a 40-day period of penance that culminates on Easter. The holiday marks the start of a period of reflection and repentance that lasts until Easter.
Wondering why a small dusty cross anoints the foreheads of Christians once a year? They're celebrating Ash Wednesday, which for many also marks the start of Lent, a 40-day period of penance and reflection leading up to Easter. Here's what you need to know about a holiday marked by ash crosses and fasting.
Ash Wednesday always falls on the Wednesday six and a half weeks before Easter, which Christians around the world believe is the day that ‚Ä¶
